data.title: All the Greater Manchester bus services that could be saved or boosted as transport bosses draw up list
data.meta_description: Transport bosses have drawn up a recommended list of potential services for each area
data.text:
Transport bosses have drawn up a list of Greater Manchester bus services that could be boosted or saved thanks to a new £1.6m pot of cash.

In a rousing speech about a public transport revolution, Boris Johnson last month announced a £220m national pot for bus services.

Of that, £30m has been earmarked for authorities outside London to restore lost bus routes where most needed, extend existing ones or launch new services.

According to a letter sent to MPs by Transport for Greater Manchester, the region has been allocated up to £1.59m from the fund.

It may be the biggest such share in the country, but transport bosses here have warned it is a 'relatively small amount of one-off funding' which will limit the 'scope and scale' of plans.

But to secure the funding, authorities now have to complete 'statements of intent' outlining how Greater Manchester Combined Authority will use the funding for the community.

For each area, transport bosses have drawn up a recommended list of potential services to save or boost.

The list could prove controversial. For example, some services, such as the 375 Stockport to Mellor route - the only route to the most remote village in Greater Manchester which was axed last month - does not feature.

Alison Chew, TfGM’s interim Head of Bus Services, said: "We have been working with bus operators, local authorities and the Greater Manchester Transport Committee to identify services that might be suitable for this funding, under the government’s Better Deal for Bus Users programme.

"As part of the process, and to ensure that our submission delivers the best outcome for the region’s bus users, we are also consulting with all Greater Manchester MPs."

She stressed that this list was 'long and subject to change', adding "not all may be able to benefit from additional funding of up to circa £1.6m."

Here are the services that could change, broken down by area:

Bolton

Service 8, Bolton-Manchester: Introduction of night journeys

Service 471, Bolton-Bury-Rochdale: Introduction of early morning journeys

Service 524, Bolton-Little Lever-Radcliffe-Bury: Increased evening frequency to every 30 minutes

Service 38, Manchester-Logistics North: Extension of some daytime journeys from Logistics North to Bolton, providing regular link including RBH

Service 273, Rawtenstall-Ramsbottom-Bolton: Introduction of hourly off-peak service, restoring previous links

Bury

Service 95, Bury-Salford: Extension to Salford Quays

Service 135, Bury-Manchester: Extension to 24 hours

Service 273, Rawtenstall-Ramsbottom-Bolton: Introduction of hourly off-peak service, restoring previous links

Services 472/474, Bury-Ramsbottom circulars: Increased evening frequency to every 30 minutes

Service 524, Bolton-Little Lever-Radcliffe-Bury: Increased frequency to every 30 minutes

Service X41, Accrington-Prestwich-Manchester: Retention of service

Service 97/98, Bury-Manchester: Introduction of early morning journeys

Service 471, Bolton-Bury-Rochdale: Introduction of early morning journeys

Manchester

Services 216 and 219, Manchester-Ashton: Additional late night trips on Fridays and Saturdays to bridge gap between current evening and night services

Service 34, Leigh-Manchester: Additional early Monday-Friday journeys

Service 33, Manchester-Worsley: Extension of route beyond Worsley to RHS Bridgewater, Boothstown and Tyldesley

Service 59, Manchester-Middleton-Oldham: Introduction of later evening trips

Service 84, Manchester-Uppermill: Introduction of later evening trips

Service 17, Rochdale-Manchester: Additional am/pm journeys to operate to Stakehill

Service 8, Bolton-Manchester: Introduction of night journeys

Service 17, Rochdale-Manchester: Introduction of night journeys

Service 97/98, Bury-Manchester: Introduction of early morning journeys

Service 19, Altrincham-Sale-Wythenshawe: Earlier Saturday morning journeys

Service 25, Stockport-intu Trafford Centre: Earlier Saturday/Sunday journeys

Service 201, Manchester-Gorton-Denton-Hyde-Hattersley: Extend hours to operate 24 hours

Service 103, World Freight Terminal to Manchester Piccadilly: Extend hours to operate 24-hour service

Services 56 and 156, Manchester-Middleton: Extension of short journeys to serve Middleton and provide through service on all journeys via NMGH

Service 83, Oldham-Manchester: Additional Monday to Saturday evening journeys, restoring previous frequency of every 20 minutes (combined 10 minute with other services)

Service 135, Bury-Manchester: Extension of service up to 24 hours

Service 38, Manchester-Logistics North: Extension of some daytime journeys from Logistics North to Bolton, providing regular link including RBH

Service 83, Oldham-Manchester: Introduction of daily 24 hour service every 30 minutes, plugging gap between existing

evening and early morning trips (currently 0500-000)

X41 - Accrington -Prestwich-Manchester: Retention of service

Service 76, Oldham-Limeside-Failsworth-Manchester: Extension of short journeys during evenings and Sunday beyond Failsworth

Oldham

Service 59, Manchester-Middleton-Oldham: Introduction of later evening trips

Service 80, Oldham-Holts Introduction of later evening trips

Service 350, Oldham-Ashton: Introduction of later evening trips

Service 409, Ashton-Oldham-Rochdale: Introduction of early morning journeys

Service 415, Middleton-Oldham: Increased frequency to half-hourly (including peak hours)

Service 83, Oldham-Manchester: Additional Monday to Saturday evening journeys, restoring previous frequency of every 20 minutes (combined 10 minute with other services)

Service 409, Ashton-Oldham-Rochdale: Additional Monday to Saturday evening journeys, restoring previous frequency of every 20 minutes

Service 409, Ashton-Oldham-Rochdale: Improved Monday to Friday off peak frequency to operate every 7/8 minutes (from 8/9 minutes)

Service 83, Oldham-Manchester: Introduction of daily 24 hour service every 30 minutes, plugging gap between existing evening and early morning trips (currently 0500-000)

Service 76, Oldham-Limeside-Failsworth-Manchester: Extension of short journeys during evenings and Sunday beyond Failsworth

Rochdale

Service 59, Manchester-Middleton-Oldham: Introduction of later evening trips

Service 17, Rochdale-Manchester: Introduction of night journeys

Service 17, Rochdale-Manchester: additional am/pm peak journeys to operate through Stakehill

Service 409, Ashton-Oldham-Rochdale: Introduction of early morning

journeys

Service 471, Bolton-Bury-Rochdale: Introduction of early morning journeys

Services 56 and 156, Manchester-Middleton: Extension of short journeys to serve Middleton and provide through service on all journeys via NMGH

Service 409, Ashton-Oldham-Rochdale: Additional Monday to Saturday evening journeys, restoring previous frequency of every 20 minutes

Service 415, Middleton-Oldham: Increased frequency to half hourly (including peak hours)

Service 409, Ashton-Oldham-Rochdale: Improved Monday to Friday off peak frequency to operate

every 7/8 minutes (from 8/9 minutes)

Salford

Service 34, Leigh-Manchester: Additional early Monday-Friday journeys

Service 33, Manchester-Worsley: Extension of route beyond Worsley to RHS Bridgewater, Boothstown and Tyldesley

Service 8, Bolton-Manchester: Introduction of night journeys

Service 97/98, Bury-Manchester: Introduction of early morning journeys

Service 68, Farnworth-Walkden-Eccles-intu Trafford Centre: Extension of service from Little Hulton to Bolton via Logistics

North

Service 95, Bury-Salford Extension of route to Salford Quays: Service 38, Manchester-Logistics North: Extension of some daytime journeys from Logistics North to Bolton, providing regular link including RBH

Stockport

Services 216 and 219, Manchester-Ashton: Additional late night trips on Fridays and Saturdays to bridge gap between current evening and night services

Service 25, Stockport-intu Trafford Centre: Earlier Saturday/Sunday journeys

Service 394, Glossop-Stepping Hill: Improve to hourly service Monday to Saturday

Tameside

Services 216 219, Manchester-Ashton: Additional late night trips on Fridays and Saturdays to bridge gap between current evening and night services

Service 84, Manchester-Uppermill: Introduction of later evening trips

Service 350, Oldham-Ashton: Introduction of later evening trips

Service 409, Ashton-Oldham-Rochdale: Introduction of early morning journeys

Service 201, Manchester-Gorton-Denton-Hyde-Hattersley: Extend hours to operate 24 hours

Service 409, Ashton-Oldham-Rochdale: Additional Monday to Saturday evening journeys, restoring previous frequency of every 20 minutes

Service 409, Ashton-Oldham-Rochdale: Improved Monday to Friday off peak frequency to operate every 7/8 minutes (from 8/9 minutes)

Service 76, Oldham-Limeside-Failsworth-Manchester: Extension of short journeys during evenings and Sunday beyond Failsworth

Trafford

Service 19, Altrincham-Sale-Wythenshawe: Earlier Saturday morning journeys

Service 25, Stockport-intuTrafford Centre: Earlier Saturday/Sunday journeys

Service 68, Farnworth-Walkden-Eccles-intu Trafford Centre: Extension of service from Little Hulton to Bolton via Logistics

North

Wigan

Service 34, Leigh-Manchester: Additional early Monday-Friday journeys

Service 68, Farnworth-Walkden-Eccles –intu Trafford Centre: Extension of service from Little Hulton to Bolton via Logistics North

Included on the list is the X41, which has already been saved by the Government. It's unclear if the money made available for this last month will be deducted from the new pot.

The list has been finalised according to a set of 'assessment criteria'. This includes whether the service can pay for itself long term, social inclusion and how it fits in with the rest of the network.

MPS have been invited to make their own suggestions on routes they would like to see saved or boosted.

James Daly, Bury North MP said he is now encouraging his constituents to tell him which routes they would like to see reinstated or boosted.

He added: "I'm happy that the money is being invested in Bury North bus services, happy about extra connectivity, but not happy at the proposals for changes in the constituencies."

Mr Daly said he would like to see more links between villages in Bury North - rather than just services connecting Bury with other towns and Manchester.

He added: "In particular, a route between Ramsbottom and Bury, a route between Bury and Pilsworth. I want more regular and better services within Bury North.

"I don't think the current proposal goes far enough but I'm very pleased that positive steps are being taken for bus service provision and better connectivity."

Mr Daly, who said he would also like clarity on how much money will be spent in his seat, added he would feed his constituents' views back to TfGM.
